content: hello welcome to bards craft I challenge you to build percent level done Gentiles
do it quickly and from cheap easily available materials and what's more
readily available than cardboard I guess the method that will give you a
good amount of inexpensive great looking tiles check out my take on the challenge
over on my channel Frankie D crafter after you're done here obviously now
this is a good time to hide in your crafting hole so I encourage you to
build something bigger perhaps a set of dungeon or cave tiles I
already have a film a dungeon tiles so I'll give away the ones I make unless
they turn out to be really good let's see okay so the material I'll be using
his cardboard and cardstock yes looks like oats are back on the menu and
most importantly cutting noises first I made sure that the cardboard sides were
straight then I made measurements for my first size of dungeon tiles this will be
the ones most commonly used as medium long rooms or wide corridors 6 by 12
centimetres I cut these out using a sharp blade make sure your cuts are
straight so the tiles fit well together
good with only these tiles you could do it pretty much already
next I made medium wide corridors also with 12 centimeters alone but three
centimeters wide then I made two of the largest ones twelve by twelve
centimeters now for all of those who still see their measurements in under
common all of these tiles would be approximately 25 feet long in game I
encourage the rest to convert their games into metric units it's a great
change before the next step I made a few more tiles basically the same rectangle
shapes but I cut them in half yeah this little set should cover your everyday
engineering needs moving on next I cut the stone tiles from the cardstock first
I cut out these two and a half centimeter wide strips then I cut them
into squares it might just be the dull scissors but I seem to get much cleaner
cuts with the utility knife
these bits should fit well on the tiles yeah I went ahead and cut all of the
cardstock tiles in one go if you're lucky and have a paper cutter this
should be a very quick step a quick trick for acquiring more rustic
materials just empty a suitable food container if the food later and there
you go instant cardstock next I simply glued on
the bits apply dabs of PVA or hot glue and then simply place on the tiles as
you can see my tiles are crooked and of varying size as expected but that should
be no problem here you can go for different tile patterns such as this one
I chose to keep it simple so I placed all tiles like this by the way if you
have things to share or ask I invite you to join our discord a few cool things
they're all about tabletop crafting and I'm never online anyway texturing is the
next thing to do three easy steps first cut away small bits from roughly whole
of the tiles if you wanna do cracks in this way a good tip is to make angle
cuts like this this deep textures provide good edges
for dry brushing then use a pen to carve in cracks I usually start at the cracks
from where I had cut away material and then continued by making them all over
be careful not to break the cardstock I
had no problems with this but card stock can vary in quality once that is done
find yourself a good stone with this you can easily make all manners of dents and
scratches just be careful not to apply too much force or the cardboard might
get crushed looks quite good already thank you optimal lighting angle I was
actually surprised and relieved how big these were to make you can also quickly
press like on this video and if you enjoy the content do subscribe to base
code this I wanted to use this matte spray but it was too dark for spraying
outside manual brushwork will do instead and fits well with the theme of this
challenge with this black craft paint I painted carefully trying to get a thin
and clean coat these tiles don't have as deep textures as film done Gentiles
would have that's why the spray could have been better here we can see some
brush strokes not good but I was able to smudge away the streaks with a finger
but what about the sides you may ask
well don't take any of my videos too seriously the sides are good as they are
I painted a bit of black on them just for good measure I quickly worked
through all of the tiles using a dry brush paint directly from the jar seemed
to work well here I then painted a few missed spots with a small brush next I
apply the habit of gray paint on the brush removed most of it using paper and
then dry brush to the tiles when dry brushing card stock it is especially
important to not have too much paint on the brush any mess will be easily
visible here on this tile I managed to get just the right amount of paint on
the brush yeah that looks quite good compare that to the less successful
tiles and you can see the difference the ones on the left got too much paint on
them these are much better than expected so I decided some washes would be worth
the effort I mixed a blueish wash from water blue brown and black in previous
builds I have used blue tones for stones and it works quite well so why not try
that on dungeon tiles as well I went ahead and applied this on some
areas mainly into cracks and cuts using washes on cardstock and other materials
that turn soft from water works best if the excess is removed with this in mind
I made the wash a bit stronger that seemed to work well keep in mind
you can use any other color as well to give life to your dungeon tiles to bring
out even more textures I gently dry brush the tiles with an off-white as
usual I put too much paint on the brush at first good now it's getting better
the paint hits the cardstock edges very nicely here I intentionally painted some
on the flat surfaces as well so the tiles look more weathered the last dry
brush is always the most satisfying step good that's all of them let's build a
dungeon from this after checking out what Frankie has been up to alright
looking good I like how these tiles fit with his Aztec style temple these tiles
might be quicker to make but they seem to require some freehand painting not
sure though two-sided convenient you can go check out the full build on Frankie's
channel links in the descriptions back to my tiles the first good thing I
noticed is that the cardboard tiles are heavier than the film tiles also the
surface is flatter minis are less likely to tip over in rough situations about
the naked sides consider this when the rain runs out of painted surface your
players will surely understand that they can't go any further
I think this method is very good especially if you can't get your hands
on XPS foam in fact I like these tiles better than my old ones I'll keep that
